keyTakeAways: Thousands of residents in Catanduanes, a Philippine island, evacuated due to the approaching Tropical Storm Fengshen, which poses a threat of coastal flooding and strong winds.
Fengshen is expected to pass near Catanduanes with gusts up to 80km/h and a risk of 1.2-meter waves, leading to a 'minimal to moderate' coastal flood risk.
This evacuation is part of a recurring drill on Catanduanes, which is frequently the first landmass affected by Pacific cyclones.
The Philippines faces an average of 20 storms or typhoons annually, often affecting impoverished, disaster-prone communities.
Scientists link increasing storm intensity to climate change, as global warming amplifies the power of tropical cyclones.
The country is currently recovering from a series of major earthquakes and typhoons, including those in Cebu and southern Philippines, which caused deaths and triggered tsunami warnings.
Evacuations are typically conducted in advance of storms, reflecting preparedness efforts in vulnerable regions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches the Philippine island of Catanduanes, more than 9,000 residents have evacuated due to threats of coastal flooding and strong winds. The storm, forecast to pass near the island with gusts up to 80km/h and waves up to 1.2 meters, is part of a recurring pattern in which Catanduanes—often the first landmass hit by Pacific cyclones—conducts regular evacuation drills. This event occurs amid a period of heightened natural disaster activity, including recent earthquakes in Cebu and the southern Philippines, and typhoon Ragasa in September. Experts link increasing storm intensity to climate change, indicating a broader environmental trend that heightens the frequency and severity of disasters in vulnerable regions.
title: Thousands evacuate Philippine coast as Tropical Storm Fengshen approaches
